descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an introductory general biology class. Topics include (but are not limited to) evolution, cell biology, genetics, and physiology. The significance of core concepts in relation to practical life applications will be discussed, as well as how new scientific discoveries are made and how those discoveries are communicated within and beyond the research community.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No course prerequisites; open to all students with an interest in the topic but little biology background.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will be able to explain key concepts fundamental to modern life sciences, describe the process of scientific inquiry, differentiate primary from secondary publications, analyze media coverage of biological topics, and seek and synthesize biology information independently.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will be from: "Biology: Life on Earth With Physiology, tenth edition," 2014 by Teresa Audesirk, Gerald Audesirk, and Bruce E. Byers. Published by Benjamin Cummings (an imprint of Pearson). Print version ISBN-13: 978-0-321-79426-0 (ISBN-10: 0-321-79426-5) OR eText version ISBN-13: 9780321844811 (ISBN-10: 0321844815). Students who wish to use alternate study materials are encouraged to contact the instructor for guidance.
